elements.name: welcome_preamble
elements.html:
Welcome to the {course} End-of-Course Survey

Code.org relies on surveys as a crucial tool to remain connected to teachers, and to give you the opportunity to provide feedback about our curriculum and your teaching experience.

Privacy and Confidentiality

  • Your individual responses here are completely confidential.
  • Your identity will never be revealed publicly or used to tie any responses back to you personally.
  • We may share anonymous, aggregate data (representing all responses) publicly.
  • Your anonymized responses will be used by Code.org, our Regional Partners, and our facilitators for program improvement.

This survey should take about 15 minutes to complete.

At the end you will be offered a $10 Amazon gift card for your time (supplies limited to first 250 respondents).

Your honesty and candor are appreciated and help us improve.

elements.name: teaching_context_header
elements.html:
Teaching Context

This survey is about teaching with Code.org materials and resources during the 2020-21 school year.

We recognize the unique nature of teaching this year with the COVID-19 pandemic affecting most, if not all, schools. In this survey we address the impacts that COVID-19 had on your classroom, as well as some questions about using Code.org curriculum, tools and resources.

Let's get started!

elements.name: grade_levels_taught
elements.title: At what grade levels did you teach {course} this year? [select all that apply]

elements.name: csf_which_course
elements.title: Which courses of CS Fundamentals did you teach? Please check any courses you taught all or most of with students.

elements.name: question3
elements.title: How often do you do each of the following as a {course} teacher?

rows.text: Choose which lessons or activities students will complete.
Support student learning and differentiate instruction.
Teach unplugged activities along with online portions of the curriculum.
Provide opportunities for student reflection, through discussion or journaling.
Transfer learning to other contexts (e.g. cross-curricular learning or other computer science content not on Code.org).
Assess or grade student work.

elements.title: Which of the following most closely describes what using Code.org looks like in your classroom?

choices.text: Students are able to engage in Code.org lessons during time dedicated to computer science instruction.
Students engage in Code.org lessons as part of a station/rotation alongside other activities.
Students engage in Code.org if they have extra time in class, or at home.

elements.name: challenges
elements.title: Please characterize the challenges you faced with teaching your students {course}.

rows.text: Providing instruction on new concepts to my students
Providing feedback on work students have done
Finding ways for students to collaborate
Differentiating instruction for students with varying background knowledge and abilities
Finding materials to work on that don't require internet and device access
Supporting students who are completing materials early and need additional challenges
Supporting students who are not engaged in the material
Supporting students who have different levels of prior experience

elements.name: one_challenge_FR
elements.title: For one of the items you identified as a challenge, please describe any ideas you have for how Code.org might address it.

elements.name: cdo_strategies
elements.title: When teaching {course} how often did you explicitly do the following?

rows.text: Ask students to write code with another student.
Ask a student to give feedback on a classmate’s work.
Ask a student to share their ideas with classmates in small group or large group discussion.
Remind students that failure is a normal and natural part of the problem solving process.
Gave students the opportunity to write their thoughts down in a journal or on paper.

elements.name: facilitation_of_student_interest
elements.title: When teaching {course} how often did you explicitly do the following?

rows.text: Connected lessons or activities to students' lives (e.g., by asking about past experiences, or applying content to students' daily lives).
Asked students to consider relationships between lesson content and real world problems (meaning actual events or situations within or outside of school).

elements.name: facilitation_of_cog_demand
elements.title: When teaching {course} how often did you ASK STUDENTS explicitly to do the following?

rows.text: Consider alternative approaches to their work.
Explain the logic and reasoning supporting their solutions.
Explain why they agree or disagree with the work of other students.

elements.name: lms_tool_remote
elements.title: What is the primary Learning Management System (LMS) you make use of?  (If you, your school or district uses multiple LMS's please choose the one you like the most)

choices.text: None - I don't really use an LMS

elements.name: happy_with_lms
elements.title: How happy are you with your LMS?

elements.name: tool_changes_grading
elements.title: Code.org is considering updates to its teacher tools.  Which of the following potential changes would most improve your experience GRADING OR ASSESSING student work? Please rate them in terms of how important they are to you.

rows.text: Give feedback on your students' work from within your LMS, instead of within Code.org's tools
Within Code.org, be able to see, compare, and leave feedback on different students' work on a single page (no page refresh required)
Within Code.org, give feedback on or evaluate open ended questions within lessons or assessments
Within Code.org, view a summary of the grades you've given students on their work
Within your LMS, view a summary of the grades you've given students on their work
Digital rubrics available on Code.org programming levels for evaluating student work

elements.name: tool_changes_progress
elements.title: Which of the following potential changes would most improve your experience MANAGING OR TRACKING STUDENT PROGRESS? Please rate them in terms of how important they are to you.

rows.text: Assign Code.org lessons through your LMS
From within your LMS, be able to track student progress on Code.org levels and lessons
A printable PDF of class progress on levels and lessons
An interrupt at the end of each Code.org lesson that stops students from moving forward to the next lesson automatically
A way for students to say they are not finished with a level (i.e. it's not complete), even if they decide to move forward to the next level
A way to see which levels have been evaluated for correctness (and which have not) in the Progress view

elements.name: LMS_useful_integration_other

The amount of time needed to cover all the material.
My class being fully enrolled (or recruiting students into the class).
Computer science being offered by my school.
Teaching Code.org materials (specifically).
Teaching computer science (in general).
Teaching (in general).

elements.name: connectedness_to_cs_ed_community
elements.title: What are your perceptions about your connectedness to the broader CS Education community?

rows.text: I feel connected to a community of CS teachers.
When I need help teaching CS, I have someone to turn to.
I know CS teacher leaders and role models in my community.
I feel like I'm part of a broad CS education movement.

elements.name: community_values_cs
elements.title: What are your perceptions about how your school and community values and supports computer science?

rows.text: There is student demand for more computer science courses in my school.
My school leaders tell others in our school about the benefits of offering computer science.
Counselors at my school communicate the benefits of computer science to all students.
Families here think offering computer science is important.
I have strong administrative support for teaching CS.
My school administration provides me with high quality feedback and evaluation of my CS instruction.

*First 250 respondents will receive gift card. Please allow 1-2 weeks to receive code.
